column4: wait...are people giving out root logins to get help...and exchanging log-in info via PM?
if people gave me root access to their boxes...i would offer a lot more help in this channel

think you are confused... write trough means the cache immediately sends writes to the disk instead of holding them in the cache... write-back is the default behavior for pretty much all filesystems unless you mount with -o sync
was that statement direct at me? i don't recalling saying anything about sync'd and async writes
yeah, i don't thin that statement was related to...write/through write/back
in fact, i have no experience wwith ext4, just making an example that a filesystem developer can claim release status for their work...but it may still have bugs
the last thing he said was "Latest ntfs-3g claims it supports writes though =|?"
in other words, he said, "but i thought they claimed ntfs-3g supported writes"

i've had tons of trouble with it...another issue is that it lets you use all the meta-characters that windows doesn't like in filenames...if you make a file with : in ntfs-3g, boot into windows, windows will not be able to read or delete that file
you can do that from within windows too.. it's just explorer being retarded
i believe i tried deleting the file from cmd.exe and it still failed

iirc explorer chokes on a lot of characters.... all win32 apps will choke if the file name has a null character in it since the win32 api uses null to terminate the string... the NT native api uses counted strings so they can contain nulls
yea... one of the ways root kits hide files... use the native api to set the name to something with a null in it
so maybe this "problem" with ntfs-3g is actually a problem with NTFS itself
naw.... filesystem doesn't give a crap what name you use... it's a problem in the win32 apis

iirc there are some other special characters that the win32 apis process and also can't handle > 255 char names... you can disable the processing and get around that limit by using the name "\\?\full\path\to\file" as the name
